{'input': 'We need a person know HTML, CSS and JS to help with our landing page', 'output': '{"companyName": null, "jobTitle": "Front-end Developer", "domain": ["Web Development"]}'}

{'interviewer': "Hi there!  Thanks for coming in today. I'm Hải, and I'll be conducting your interview.  To start, let me just say that I'm really impressed you made it this far in the process.  We're excited to learn more about you and your skills.  Before we begin, is there anything you'd like to ask me?\n", 'candidate': "No, I'm good"}

{'interviewer': "Great! Let's start with your experience.  To get a better understanding of your background, could you tell me about a project where you had to work extensively with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript? What was your role, and what challenges did you face?\n", 'candidate': 'I once work as a front-end developer for a school project. It a website that let user browse our school images and videos. The most challenging part is learning to use REST API. It was a new concept for me at that point'}

{'interviewer': "That sounds like a valuable learning experience.  Working with APIs is a crucial skill for front-end developers.  Can you elaborate on how you learned to use the REST API in that project? What resources did you use, and what specific challenges did you encounter while integrating the API into your website?  I'm particularly interested in how you handled any unexpected errors or issues that arose during the development process.\n", 'candidate': 'I learned to use REST API mostly by watching youtube videos, one particular challenges that I found very hard is handling promises in JavaScript since I used the fetch API to send requests. About the errors case. Our school server is pretty crappy so any time more than 1000 user visit the website at once, the server need tr in mind. First I set a short timeout for the request, if the first request failed, the client will wait for 30s and fire another request, after 5 failed request, the client show error to the user'}

{'interviewer': "That's great you took the initiative to learn through YouTube tutorials.  Handling asynchronous operations with promises in JavaScript is definitely a key skill.  Your approach to handling server-side issues with retries and timeouts is also practical and shows good problem-solving skills.  Let's shift gears a bit.  In the job description, we mentioned building landing pages.  Imagine we need a landing page with a simple form for email sign-ups.  How would you approach designing and implementing this, considering both functionality and user experience?  Let's focus on the HTML, CSS, and basic JavaScript aspects.  You don't need to write complete code; just describe your approach and the key elements you'd include.\n", 'candidate': 'Do we need a password field or just a field for email'}

{'interviewer': "Just an email field for simplicity's sake.  Let's focus on the core functionality of collecting an email address.\n", 'candidate': "I'll start with a form element, it has 2 child: an input with type email and submit button, the form will have an onssubmit callback, the callback will check the validity of the email using regex, if the email is valid, the submit event will go through, if not, i will cancel the event and make the input field red"}
